$$
\begin{aligned}
0=\alpha_{I}\left(\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}\right. & \left.\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)+\frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right)+\alpha_{U} \widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}\left(H_{0, \iota}\right) \\
=\alpha_{I} \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{Y}) & \left(H_{0, \iota}-P_{I}^{-1} P_{X \mid G} V_{0, p, \iota}(\mathcal{Y})\right) \\
& \left.+\alpha_{U}\left(P_{U, \iota}(\mathcal{Y}) H_{0, \iota}-\left(P_{U, \iota}(\mathcal{Y})+P_{X}\right) p_{\iota}\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)(\mathcal{Y})\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using (53) it is clear that $V_{0, p, \iota}(\mathcal{Y})=0$. To eliminate the $H_{0, \iota}$ terms we need

$$
0_{d}=\alpha_{I} \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{Y})+\alpha_{U} P_{U, \iota}(\mathcal{Y})-\alpha_{U}\left(P_{U, \iota}(\mathcal{Y})+P_{X}\right) M_{p, \iota}(\mathcal{Y}) \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{Y})
$$

Re-writing this equation slightly, and translating back to the un-demeaned values, we obtain
Proposition A.3. Assume $\widehat{\mathcal{Y}}$ enforces the matrix equality

$$
0_{d}=\frac{\alpha_{I}}{\alpha_{U}} 1_{d}+P_{U, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{Y}}) \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{Y})^{-1}-\left(P_{U, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{Y}})+P_{X}\right) M_{p, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{Y}})
$$

where $M_{p, \iota}, \mathcal{M}, P_{U, \iota}$ are from (49), (51), (52). Then, there is a price-impact equilibrium. The market signal is

$$
H_{\iota}=H_{0, \iota}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}=G+\Lambda_{\iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{Y}}) Z_{N}
$$

where $\Lambda_{\iota}$ is from (51). The equilibrium price is

$$
p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+M_{p, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{Y}}) \mathcal{M}(\widehat{\mathcal{Y}})\left(H_{\iota}-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)
$$

The risk-aversion adjusted optimal policies are

$$
\begin{gathered}
\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}=\widehat{\Pi}+P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}(1+\widehat{\mathcal{F}})^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{F}})^{-1} G \\
-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right) \\
\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota}=\widehat{\Pi}+P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+P_{U, \iota} H_{\iota}-\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right) p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

In light of Proposition A.3, our goal is to find solutions $\widehat{\mathcal{F}}$ to (58). This is a matrix-valued cubic equation for $\mathcal{Y}$ and the primary difficulty in establishing existence of solutions $\widehat{\mathcal{F}}$ arises due to the interaction between the precision matrices $P_{I}, P_{N}$ and $P_{X}$. While techniques exist for solving such equations (see Benzi and Viviani [2023]), technically this would take us far beyond our intended scope, and therefore we make the following assumption, which is always valid in the case of a single asset.
Assumption A.4. $P_{I}=p_{I} P_{X}$ and $P_{N}=p_{N} P_{X}^{-1}$ for scalars $p_{I}, p_{N}>0$.
Under this assumption we guess $\mathcal{Y}=y 1_{d}$ for a scalar $y>0$. The quantities in (49), (51) and (52) take the form

$$
M_{p, \iota}=\frac{y}{1+p_{I}} P_{X}^{-1}, \quad \mathcal{M}=\frac{p_{I}}{1+2 y} P_{X}, \quad \Lambda_{\iota}=\frac{y+1}{\alpha_{I} p_{I}} P_{X}^{-1}, \quad P_{U, \iota}=p_{U, \iota} P_{X}
$$

where using the notation of (7) we have

$$
p_{U, \iota}:=\left(\frac{\kappa p_{I}^{2}}{(1+y)^{2}+\kappa p_{I}}\right)
$$

By plugging in these values and simplifying one can show that (58) holds if and only if $y$ solves (6). Indeed

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{U, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}) \mathcal{M}(\mathcal{Y})^{-1} & +\frac{\alpha_{I}}{\alpha_{U}} 1_{d}-\left(P_{U, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{F}})+P_{X}\right) M_{p, \iota}(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}) \\
& =\left(\frac{\kappa p_{I}(1+2 y)}{(1+y)^{2}+\kappa p_{I}}+\frac{\lambda}{1-\lambda}-\left(1+\frac{\kappa p_{I}^{2}}{(1+y)^{2}+\kappa p_{I}}\right) \frac{y}{1+p_{I}}\right) 1_{d}
\end{aligned}
$$

The quantity within the parentheses simplifies to

$$
\frac{\lambda}{(1-\lambda)\left((1+y)^{2}+\kappa p_{I}\right)}\left((1+y)^{2}\left(1-\frac{1-\lambda}{\lambda\left(1+p_{I}\right)} y\right)+\frac{\kappa p_{I}}{\lambda}((1-\lambda) y+1)\right)
$$

and the term within the parentheses on the right is exactly the right side of (6). Therefore, using Proposition 1.1 we obtain the following generalization of Theorem 1.2.
Theorem A.5. Let Assumption A. 4 hold. Then a price-impact equilibrium exists. Using $\widehat{y}$ from Proposition 1.1, the market signal is $H_{\iota}$ from (59). The equilibrium price is $p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)$ from (60). The optimal policies for the insider and uninformed trader are from (61).
Price-taking equilibrium. For the price-taking results, assume there is a market signal $H$ revealed by the time 0 price $p=p(H)$, and both traders take $p(H)$ as given. The insider has time 0 information $\sigma(H, G)$ while the uninformed trader uses $\sigma(H)$. We make the same translations as in the price-impact case (with the obvious notation) so that the insider and uninformed trader's optimal investment problems are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (1) } \quad \inf _{\theta \in \sigma\left(G_{0}, H_{0}\right)} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\theta^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, H_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \text { (U) } \quad \inf _{\theta \in \sigma\left(H_{0}\right)} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\theta^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The clearing condition is again (44). Provided we find a market-clearing signal $H_{0}$ and price $p_{0}$ for the above optimization problems, the equilibrium signal and price will be $H=H_{0}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}$ and

$p=p_{0}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}$ respectively, and the optimal risk aversion adjusted policies will be $\widehat{\psi}_{i}=\widehat{\theta}_{i}+\widehat{\Pi}, i \in$ $\{I, U\}$. As this result does not require Assumption A. 4 we state it for general parameter values in the following.
Proposition A.6. There is a price-taking equilibrium. The market signal is

$$
H=H_{0}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}=G_{0}+\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} P_{I}^{-1} Z_{N}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}=G+\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} P_{I}^{-1} Z_{N}
$$

$H$ is of the same form as $G$, but with lower precision

$$
P_{U}:=\left(P_{I}^{-1}+\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}^{2}} P_{I}^{-1} P_{N}^{-1} P_{I}^{-1}\right)^{-1}
$$

The equilibrium price is

$$
p(H)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\left(\alpha_{I}\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right)+\alpha_{U}\left(P_{U}+P_{X}\right)\right)^{-1}\left(\alpha_{I} P_{I}+\alpha_{U} P_{U}\right)\left(H-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)
$$

The optimal policies for $I$ and $U$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \widehat{\psi}_{I}=\widehat{\Pi}+P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+P_{I} G-\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right) p(H) \\
& \widehat{\psi}_{U}=\widehat{\Pi}+P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+P_{U} H-\left(P_{U}+P_{X}\right) p(H)
\end{aligned}
$$

No private signal (NS) equilibrium. We next state the equilibrium results, generalizing Proposition 1.4) for no private signal. These results are valid under Assumption A.4. Here, with the notation of (7) $P_{U}$ from (66) reduces to (compare with (63))

$$
P_{U}=p_{U} P_{X} ; \quad p_{U}:=\left(\frac{\kappa p_{I}^{2}}{1+\kappa p_{I}}\right) P_{X}
$$

which shows that $p_{U} \rightarrow 0$ as $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$ on the order of $p_{I}^{2}$.
Proposition A.7. Under Assumption A.4, the no-signal equilibrium corresponds to $p_{I}=0$. In the price-taking case, the equilibrium price and the risk aversion adjusted optimal positions are

$$
p_{n s}=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\lambda P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}} ; \quad \widehat{\psi}_{n s, I}=\widehat{\psi}_{n s, U}=\widehat{\Pi}-\lambda \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
$$

where $\lambda$ is defined in (7). In the price-impact case, the equilibrium price is

$$
p_{n s, \iota}=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{\lambda}{1-\lambda^{2}} P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
$$

The risk aversion adjusted optimal policies for $I$ and $U$ are

$$
\widehat{\psi}_{n s, \iota, I}=\widehat{\Pi}-\frac{\lambda}{1+\lambda} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}} ; \quad \widehat{\psi}_{n s, \iota, U}=\widehat{\Pi}-\frac{\lambda}{1-\lambda^{2}} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
$$

# APPENDix B. Proofs 

B.1. Proofs from Section 1. In this section, we first prove the cubic equation result Proposition 1.1. We then translate the general equilibrium results of Theorem A.5, Proposition A. 6 and Proposition A. 7 into the forms given in Theorem 1.2, Proposition 1.3 and Proposition 1.4 respectively.

Proof of Proposition 1.1. Define $g(y)$ as the cubic function on the right side of (6). It is clear that $g(0)>0$ and $\lim _{y \rightarrow \infty} g(y)=-\infty$. This shows there exists a solution $\widehat{y}>0$ to $g(\widehat{y})=0$. As for uniqueness of positive solutions, straight-forward computations show for any solution to $g(y)=0$ that

$$
(1+y) \dot{g}(y)=-\frac{1-\lambda}{\lambda}(1+y) \kappa p_{I}-\kappa p_{I}-(1+y)^{3} \frac{1-\lambda}{\lambda\left(1+p_{I}\right)}<0
$$

Thus, for any solution $y>-1, g$ strictly decreasing at $y$ and hence there is a unique solution exceeding -1 , which is in fact positive.

B.1.1. Theorem 1.2 from Theorem A.5. Throughout, we use that in Section $1, P_{X}=1, \mu_{X}=0$. We also use Assumption A.4. We start with the market signal. Here, (9) follows from (59) and (62) (throughout at $y=\widehat{y}$ ). The precision $p_{U, \iota}$ in (10) is immediate from (7) and (62). The price in (11) is immediate from (60) and (62).

The insider and uninformed trader's policy in (13) follows from (61) and (8) using (62). The slope $M_{p, \iota}$ follows from (62), and the intercept $V_{p, \iota}$ follows from (45) and (8) given the translation $V_{p, \iota}=V_{0, p, \iota}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}$ and the fact we showed (see right below (56)) that $V_{0, p, \iota}=0$.

The market signal in (15) follows immediately from (65). The precision $p_{U}$ in (16) is immediate from (69). The price $p$ in (17) follows directly from (7), (67) and (69). The trading strategies for $I, U$ are immediate given (68) and (8).
B.1.3. Proposition 1.4 from Proposition A.7. This is an immediate consequence of Proposition A. 7 given Assumption A. 4 and that in Section $1, P_{X}=1, \mu_{X}=0$.
B.2. Proofs from Appendix A. To ease notation, throughout all proofs of this section we omit the $p, \iota$ subscript from $M_{p, \iota}, V_{0, p, \iota}$ in the price response function $p_{\iota}$ from (48), and we omit the functional dependence on $\mathcal{Y}$.

Proof of Lemma A.1. The $\mathbb{Q}_{0}$ law of $X_{0}$ given $\sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)$ has density

$$
\frac{\mathbb{Q}_{0}\left[X_{0} \in d x\left[\sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]\right.}{\mathbb{Q}_{0}\left[X_{0} \in d x\right]}=\left.\left(\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime} P_{I} x+x^{\prime} P_{I} g}}{\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{1}{2} X_{0}^{\prime} P_{I} X+X_{0}^{\prime} P_{I} g}\right]}\right)\right|_{g=G_{0}}
$$

Using this in (48), on $\left\{G_{0}=g, Z_{N}=z\right\}$ the insider minimizes over $\theta=\theta(g, z)$

$$
\theta^{\prime}\left(M\left(\theta+\frac{z}{\alpha_{I}}\right)+V_{0}\right)+\log \left(\frac{\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\theta^{\prime} X_{0}-\frac{1}{2} X_{0}^{\prime} P_{I} X_{0}+X_{0}^{\prime} P_{I} g}\right]}{\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{1}{2} X_{0}^{\prime} P_{I} X_{0}+X_{0}^{\prime} P_{I} g}\right]}\right)
$$

As $X_{0} \stackrel{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}{\sim} N\left(0, P_{X}^{-1}\right)$, this specifies to (using $\theta^{\prime} M \theta=(1 / 2) \theta^{\prime}\left(M+M^{\prime}\right) \theta$ )

$$
\frac{1}{2} \theta^{\prime}\left(M+M^{\prime}+P_{X \mid G}^{-1}\right) \theta-\theta^{\prime} P_{X \mid G}^{-1}\left(P_{I} g-P_{X \mid G}\left(M \frac{z}{\alpha_{I}}+V_{0}\right)\right)
$$

Using $M$ as in (49), the optimizer $\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}$ is

$$
\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}(g, z)=P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\mathcal{Y}+\mathcal{Y}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{I} g-P_{X \mid G} V_{0}-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \mathcal{Y} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} \frac{z}{\alpha_{I}}\right)
$$

The identity in (50) with $\mathcal{M}, \Lambda_{\iota}, \mathcal{V}$ from (51) follow by direct computation.
Proof of Lemma A.2. Using (52) one can show the $\mathbb{Q}_{0}$ law of $X_{0}$ given $\sigma\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)$ has density

$$
\frac{\mathbb{Q}_{0}\left[X_{0} \in d x\left[\sigma\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right]\right.}{\mathbb{Q}_{0}\left[X_{0} \in d x\right]}=\left.\left(\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime} P_{U, \iota} x+x^{\prime} P_{U, \iota} h}}{\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{1}{2} X_{0}^{\prime} P_{U, \iota} X_{0}+X_{0}^{\prime} P_{U, \iota} h}\right]}\right)\right|_{h=H_{0, \iota}}

Using this in (54) and that $X_{0} \stackrel{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}{\sim} N\left(0, P_{X}^{-1}\right)$, on $\left\{H_{0, \iota}=h\right\}$ the uninformed trader minimizes over $\theta=\theta(h)$

$$
\frac{1}{2} \theta^{\prime}\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right)^{-1}\right) \theta-\theta^{\prime}\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right)^{-1}\left(P_{U, \iota} h-\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right) p_{\iota}(h)\right)

(55) is immediate.

Proof of Proposition A.3. Throughout we suppress the dependence of all functions on $\mathcal{Y}$. First, (58) follows directly from (57) after dividing by $\alpha_{U}$ and right-multiplying by $\mathcal{M}^{-1}$. As such, provided there is a solution $\widehat{\mathcal{F}}$ the price impact equilibrium follows with market signal $H_{\iota}$ from (59) and price $p_{\iota}$ from (60). The remainder of the proof identifies the policies in (61) starting with the uninformed trader. Here, using $\widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}$ from (55), (47) and $\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota}=\widehat{\Pi}+\widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}$ we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota} & =\widehat{\Pi}+P_{U, \iota}\left(H_{\iota}-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right)\left(p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right) \\
& =\widehat{\Pi}+P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+P_{U, \iota} H_{\iota}-\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right) p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As for $I$ our goal is to write the strategy in the same form as for $U$, i.e. as a linear function of $\widehat{\Pi}, p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}, G_{0}$ and $p_{\iota}$. Starting with $\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}$ in (73) (at $g=G_{0}=G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}$ and using that in equilibrium $\left.V_{0, p, \iota}=0\right)$ and $\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}=\widehat{\Pi}+\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}$ we find

$$
\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}=\widehat{\Pi}+P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{I}\left(G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right)
$$

Next, from (47), (52) and (53) at $V_{0, p, \iota}=0$ we find

$$
Z_{N}=\Lambda_{\iota}^{-1} \mathcal{M}^{-1} M_{p, \iota}^{-1}\left(p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\Lambda_{\iota}^{-1}\left(G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)
$$

This gives $\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}=\widehat{\Pi}+\mathbf{M}_{1} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\mathbf{M}_{2} G+\mathbf{M}_{3} p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)$ where

$$
\mathbf{M}_{1}=P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(-P_{I}-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} \frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}^{-1}\left(1_{d}-\mathcal{M}^{-1} M_{p, \iota}^{-1}\right)\right)
$$

From (49), (51) we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M}_{1}= & P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(-P_{I}-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} P_{I}\left(1_{d}\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.-P_{I}^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right) \widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\right)\right) \\
= & P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} P_{I}\right. \\
& \left.\left.+P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\right)\right. \\
= & P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(-P_{I}+P_{X \mid G}\right)=P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} P_{X}
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M}_{2} & =P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{I}+P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} \frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}^{-1}\right) \\
& =P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{I} \alpha_{I} \Lambda_{\iota}+P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\right) \frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}^{-1} \\
& =P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right) P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}+P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2}\right) \frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}^{-1} \\
& =\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Lastly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{M}_{3} & =-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} \times P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \widehat{\mathcal{F}} P_{X \mid G}^{-1 / 2} \frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \Lambda_{\iota}^{-1} \mathcal{M}^{-1} M_{p, \iota}^{-1} \\
& =-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}+1_{d}\right)^{-1} \widehat{\mathcal{F}}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right) \widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2} \\
& =-P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}\left(1_{d}+\widehat{\mathcal{F}}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} P_{X \mid G}^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Proposition A.6. Assume $H_{0}$ takes the form $H_{0}=G_{0}+\Lambda Z_{N}$ for some to-be-determined matrix $\Lambda$ and that the price is $p_{0}=p_{0}\left(H_{0}\right)$. $$
\frac{1}{2} \theta^{\prime}\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right)^{-1} \theta-\theta^{\prime}\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right)^{-1}\left(P_{I} G_{0}-\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right) p_{0}\left(H_{0}\right)\right)

Similarly, as the uninformed signal is $H_{0}=$ $X_{0}+\left(Y_{I}+\Lambda Z_{N}\right)$ it is of the same form as the insiders, just with precision $P_{U}$ instead of $P_{I}$. This gives $\Lambda=\left(1 / \alpha_{I}\right) P_{I}^{-1}$ and hence the market signal in (65) as well as precision $p_{U}$ in (66). $p_{0}$ takes the form

$$
p_{0}\left(H_{0}\right)=\left(\alpha_{I}\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right)+\alpha_{U}\left(P_{U}+P_{X}\right)\right)^{-1}\left(\alpha_{I} P_{I}+\alpha_{U} P_{U}\right) H_{0}

which yields the price in (67). Lastly, using $\widehat{\psi}_{I}=\widehat{\theta}_{I}+\widehat{\Pi}$ and $\widehat{\psi}_{U}=\widehat{\theta}_{U}+\widehat{\Pi}$ and $p(H)=p_{o}\left(H_{0}\right)-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}$ we obtain (68).

The proof of Proposition A.7, as well as those in both Sections B.3 and B. 4 simplify if we adjust the notation in (7) by defining

$$
\beta:=\kappa p_{I}=\alpha_{I}^{2} p_{I} p_{N} ; \quad \lambda_{I}:=\frac{\alpha_{I}}{\alpha_{I}+\alpha_{U}} ; \quad \lambda_{U}:=\frac{\alpha_{U}}{\alpha_{I}+\alpha_{U}}, \quad R:=\frac{1}{1+p_{I}}
$$

The cubic equation (6) becomes

$$
0=(1+y)^{2}\left(1-\frac{\lambda_{U} R}{\lambda_{I}} y\right)+\beta\left(\frac{\lambda_{U}}{\lambda_{I}}(1+y)+1\right)

Next, under Assumption A. 4 the constants $p_{U, \iota}$ from (63) and $p_{U}$ from (69) are

$$
p_{U, \iota}:=\frac{(1-R) \beta}{R\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)} ; \quad p_{U}=\frac{(1-R) \beta}{R(1+\beta)}
$$

The matrices of Proposition A. 6 are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha_{I} P_{I}+\alpha_{U} P_{U} & =\frac{\left(\alpha_{I}+\alpha_{U}\right)(1-R)\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)}{R(1+\beta)} P_{X} \\
\alpha_{I}\left(P_{I}+P_{X}\right)+\alpha_{U}\left(P_{U}+P_{X}\right) & =\frac{\left(\alpha_{I}+\alpha_{U}\right)\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)}{R(1+\beta)} P_{X}
\end{aligned}
$$

Lastly, from (39), (47), Assumption A. 4 and (77) we obtain

$$
X_{0}=P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{X} ; \quad G_{0}=X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I} ; \quad \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}=\sqrt{\frac{1-R}{\beta R}} P_{X}^{1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{N}
$$

where $\mathcal{E}_{X}, \mathcal{E}_{I}, \mathcal{E}_{N}$ are three independent $N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$ random variables under $\mathbb{Q}_{0}$. This implies we can write $H_{0}$ from (52) as (see (79))

$$
H_{0}=X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{R}{\alpha_{I}(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}
$$

Proof of Proposition A.7. We use the notation in (77), and suppress $\widehat{y}$ from $M_{p, \iota}, \mathcal{M}$. We start with the price taking equilibria. Using (80) and (82) the price $p(H)$ from (67) is

$$
p(H)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{(1-R)\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)}{\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}}\left(X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{R}{\alpha_{I}(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}\right)
$$

From (77) we see that $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$ implies $R \rightarrow 1, \beta \rightarrow 0$. Therefore, almost surely

$$
\lim _{p_{I} \rightarrow 0} p(H)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{\lambda_{I}}{\left(\lambda_{I}+\lambda_{U}\right)} P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\lambda_{I} P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
$$

because $\lambda_{U}+\lambda_{I}=1$. This gives the pricing formula in (70) as $\lambda=\lambda_{I}$. As for the positions, from $(68),(79)$ and (81) we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\psi}_{I}= & \widehat{\Pi}+\frac{1-R}{R} P_{X}\left(X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}\right)-\frac{1}{R} P_{X}\left(p(H)-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right) \\
\widehat{\psi}_{U}= & \widehat{\Pi}+\frac{(1-R) \beta}{R(1+\beta)} P_{X}\left(X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{R}{\alpha_{I}(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}\right) \\
& -\left(1+\frac{(1-R) \beta}{R(1+\beta)}\right)\left(p(H)-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, almost surely as $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \widehat{\psi}_{I} \rightarrow \widehat{\Pi}-P_{X}\left(\lambda_{I} P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right)=\widehat{\Pi}-\lambda_{I} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}} \\
& \widehat{\psi}_{U} \rightarrow \widehat{\Pi}-P_{X}\left(\lambda_{I} P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right)=\widehat{\Pi}-\lambda_{I} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We next consider the price impact equilibrium. First, from (52), (62) and (81) we find

$$
H_{0, \iota}=X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{(1+\widehat{y}) R}{\alpha_{I}(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}
$$

From (60) and (62) we obtain

$$
p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{\widehat{y}(1-R)}{1+2 \widehat{y}}\left(X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{(1+\widehat{y}) R}{\alpha_{I}(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N} .\right)
$$

From (77) and (78) we see that $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$ additionally implies $\widehat{y} \rightarrow \lambda_{I} / \lambda_{U}$. Therefore, almost surely, and using $\lambda_{U}+\lambda_{I}=1$ we find

$$
\lim _{p_{I} \rightarrow 0} p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{\lambda_{I}}{1-\lambda_{I}^{2}} P_{X}^{-1} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
$$

As for the trading strategies, from (47), (61), (62) and (79) e find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}= & \widehat{\Pi}+\frac{1}{1+\widehat{y}} P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{1-R}{R(1+\widehat{y})} P_{X}\left(X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\frac{R}{1+\widehat{y}} P_{X} p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right) \\
\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota}= & \widehat{\Pi}+P_{X} p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{(1-R) \beta}{R(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}} P_{X}\left(X_{0}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{(1+\widehat{y}) R}{\alpha_{I}(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}+p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\frac{\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}}{R(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}} P_{X} p_{\iota}\left(H_{\iota}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This gives the almost sure limits as $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$

$$
\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota} \rightarrow \widehat{\Pi}-\frac{\lambda_{I}}{1+\lambda_{I}} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}} ; \quad \widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota} \rightarrow \widehat{\Pi}-\frac{\lambda_{I}}{1-\lambda_{I}^{2}} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}
$$

B.3. Proofs from Sections 2 \& 4. As in Section B.2, throughout all proofs of this section we omit the $p, \iota$ subscript from $M_{p, \iota}, V_{p, \iota}$ in the price response function $p_{i}$ from (5).

Proof of Proposition 2.1. The first statement follows directly from (23) and $\widehat{y}>0$. For the second, using (79) with $P_{X}=1$ we see that $p_{U}>p_{U, \iota}$ is equivalent to $1<(1+\widehat{y})^{2}$, which holds as $\widehat{y}>0$.

Proof of Proposition 2.2. The formula for $p_{i}$ in (24) is taken directly from (11). As for $p$, using (17) and (80) we find

$$
p(h)=p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}+\frac{(1-R)\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)}{\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}}\left(h-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)
$$

The expression in (11) follows by the identifications in (77) and (7).
Proof of Proposition 2.3. We retain the notation in (77) and suppress $\widehat{y}$ from the $M, \mathcal{M}$ functions. First, using (25) we readily get that $2\left(m_{g}-m_{g, \iota}\right) /(1-R)=1 /(1+2 \widehat{y})+\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}-\lambda_{U} R\right) /(\beta+$ $\left.\lambda_{I}+\lambda_{U} R\right)$. This gives the result when $\beta+\lambda_{I}>\lambda_{U} R$. When $\lambda_{U} R>\beta+\lambda_{I}$, define $\bar{g}$ through $1 /(1+2 \widehat{y})=\left(\lambda_{U} R-\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}\right)\right) /\left(\lambda_{U} R+\beta+\lambda_{I}\right)$. Thus, $m_{g}>m_{g, \iota}$ if and only if $\widehat{y}<\bar{y}$. In the proof of Proposition 1.1 we showed if we define $g$ by the right side of (6) (see also (78)), then $g$ is strictly decreasing at $\widehat{y}$. Thus, if $g(\widehat{y})<0$ it must be that $\widehat{y}<\bar{y}$. Indeed, $\widehat{y}=\widehat{y}$ is not possible, and if $\widehat{y}>\bar{y}$ then there must be some $\bar{y}>0$ with $g(\bar{y})=0$, but by the uniqueness statement in Proposition 1.1 we know this is not possible as well.

It therefore suffices to show that $g(\widehat{y})<0$. To this end, write $p:=\lambda_{U} R$ and $q:=\beta+\lambda_{I}$ so that by assumption $p>q$ and $\widehat{y}=q /(p-q)$ and $\widehat{y}+1=p /(p-q)$. In (78) we obtain

$$
g(\widehat{y})=\frac{p^{2}}{(p-q)^{2}}\left(1-\frac{p q}{\lambda_{I}(p-q)}\right)+\frac{\lambda_{U} p \beta}{\lambda_{I}(p-q)}+\beta
$$

As the common denominator $\lambda_{I}(p-q)^{3}$ is positive, we need only show the numerator is negative. The numerator is $\lambda_{I} p^{2}(p-q)-p^{3} q+\lambda_{U} p \beta(p-q)^{2}+\beta \lambda_{I}(p-q)^{3}$. If we group terms by powers of $p$ the cubic terms vanish, leaving

$$
-\left(2 \beta+\lambda_{I}(1+\beta)\right) q p^{2}+\left(\lambda_{U}+3 \lambda_{I}\right) \beta q^{2} p-\beta \lambda_{I} q^{3}
$$

Since $p>q$, the derivative of the above expression is bounded above by $-q^{2}\left(3 \beta+2 \lambda_{I}\right)<0$. Thus, (85) is decreasing in $p$ when $p>q$ and hence bounded above by $-q^{3}\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}\right)<0$. The numerator is negative, finishing the result.

Proof of Proposition 2.4. We again suppress $\widehat{y}$. Using (77) we have $m_{\widehat{X}}=\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}\right) / \lambda_{U}$ and $m_{\widehat{X}, \iota}=$ $R \widehat{y}$. Therefore, $m_{\widehat{X}}>m_{\widehat{X}, \iota}$ if and only if $\widehat{y}<\bar{y}:=\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}\right) /\left(\lambda_{U} R\right)$. We will show $g(\widehat{y})<0$ for $g$ defined by the right side of (78), and this will give the result, as the proof of Proposition 2.3 showed for $y>0$ that $g(y)<0$ if and only if $y>\widehat{y}$. To this end, from (78), $g(\widehat{y})=\left(\lambda_{U} R+\beta+\lambda_{I}\right)^{2}\left(1-\beta+\lambda_{I} / \lambda_{I}\right) /\left(\lambda_{U}^{2} R^{2}\right)+\beta\left(\lambda_{U} R+\beta+\lambda_{I}\right) /\left(R \lambda_{I}\right)+\beta$, which equal to $-\beta\left[\lambda_{U} R\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}\right)\left(1+\lambda_{I}\right)+\left(\beta+\lambda_{I}\right)^{2}\right] /\left(\lambda_{I} \lambda_{U}^{2} R^{2}\right)$, where we have used that $\lambda_{I}+\lambda_{U}=1$. The result follows as $\beta, \lambda_{I}, \lambda_{U}, R>0$.

Proof of Proposition 4.1. Using (77), the expected value in (37) is negative if and only if $\widehat{y}>\bar{y}:=$ $\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right) /\left(2 R \lambda_{U}\right)$. Next, as shown in the proof of Propositions $2.3,2.4$, if we define function $g$ by the right side of (78) then $\widehat{y}>\bar{y}$ if and only if $g(\bar{y})>0$. Direct calculation yields $g(\bar{y})=$ $\beta\left[\left(\lambda_{I} / \beta-1\right)\left(2 R \lambda_{U}+\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)^{2} /\left(8 \lambda_{I} \lambda_{U}^{2} R^{2}\right)+4 \beta R \lambda_{U}^{2}\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+2 R\right)\right]$. Now, let $\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0$ while keeping everything else fixed. From (77) we see $\lambda_{I} / \beta \rightarrow \infty, \lambda_{I} \rightarrow 0, \lambda_{U} \rightarrow 1$ and $R$ is fixed. This implies that $g(\bar{y})>0$ and hence $\widehat{y}>\bar{y}$. Conversely, when $\alpha_{I} \rightarrow \infty$ we see $\lambda_{I} / \beta \rightarrow 0, \beta \rightarrow \infty, \lambda_{I} \rightarrow 1$, $\lambda_{U} \rightarrow 0$ and $R$ is fixed. This implies that $g(\bar{y})<0$ and hence $\widehat{y}<\bar{y}$.

B.4. Utility formulas used in Section 3. We prove utility results for the setup in Appendix A, under Assumption A. 4 and using the notation in (77). We will start with the price impact case, and then proceed to the price taking case. Throughout we recall the initial endowments in (1) and recall that $\widehat{\mathcal{F}}=\widehat{y} 1_{d}$ for $\widehat{y}$ from Proposition 1.1. We also use the conditional laws (similar to (71), (74)) for $k \in\{\iota, \}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mathbb{P}\left[X \in d x \mid \sigma\left(G, Z_{N}\right)\right]}{\mathbb{P}[X \in d x]} & =\left.\left(\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime} P_{I} x+x^{\prime} P_{I} g}}{\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\frac{1}{2} X^{\prime} P_{I} X+X^{\prime} P_{I} g}\right]}\right)\right|_{g=G} \\
\frac{\mathbb{P}\left[X \in d x \mid \sigma\left(H_{k}\right)\right]}{\mathbb{P}[X \in d x]} & =\left.\left(\frac{e^{-\frac{1}{2} x^{\prime} P_{U, k} x+x^{\prime} P_{U, k} h}}{\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\frac{1}{2} X^{\prime} P_{U, k} X+X^{\prime} P_{U, k} h}\right]}\right)\right|_{h=H_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

This allows us to define the "certainty equivalents", valid under Assumption A.4, and using the notation in (77)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{CE}_{I, 0}^{o}(G):=-\alpha_{I} \log \left(\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X} \mid \sigma\left(G, Z_{N}\right)\right]\right)=-\frac{\alpha_{I} R}{2}\left(\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \widehat{\Pi}-2 \widehat{\Pi}^{\prime}\left(\mu_{X}+\frac{1-R}{R} G\right)\right) \\
& \mathrm{CE}_{U, \iota}^{o}\left(H_{\iota}\right):=-\alpha_{U} \log \left(\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X} \mid \sigma\left(H_{\iota}\right)\right]\right)=-\frac{\alpha_{U}}{2\left(1+p_{U, \iota}\right)}\left(\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \widehat{\Pi}-2 \widehat{\Pi}^{\prime}\left(\mu_{X}+p_{U, \iota} H_{\iota}\right)\right) \\
& \mathrm{CE}_{U}^{o}(H):=-\alpha_{U} \log \left(\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X} \mid \sigma(H)\right]\right)=-\frac{\alpha_{U}}{2\left(1+p_{U}\right)}\left(\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \widehat{\Pi}-2 \widehat{\Pi}^{\prime}\left(\mu_{X}+p_{U} H\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $p_{U, \iota}, p_{U}$ are from (79). Lastly, extending (26) to the general setup of Appendix B.2, we define the certainty equivalent absent private information

$$
\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{i}:=\alpha_{i} \log \left(\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X}\right]\right)=\alpha_{i}\left(\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} \mu_{X}-\frac{1}{2} \widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \widehat{\Pi}\right), \quad i \in\{I, U\}
$$

Price impact certainty equivalents. In this section our goal is to prove the following.
Proposition B.1. Using the notation of (77), and $\widehat{y}$ from Proposition 1.1, the interim price impact certainty equivalents of Section 3 are

$$
\begin{aligned}
C E_{0, \iota}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right) & =C E_{I, 0}^{o}(G)+\frac{\alpha_{I} R}{2(1+2 \widehat{y})}\left|\frac{1-R}{R} P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\widehat{y} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2} \\
C E_{0, \iota}^{U}\left(H_{\iota}\right) & =C E_{U, 0}^{o}\left(H_{\iota}\right)+\frac{\alpha_{U} \lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)^{2}\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)}{2 \lambda_{U}^{2} R\left(\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}\left|P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(H_{\iota}-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The ex-ante price impact certainty equivalents of Section 3 are

$$
\begin{aligned}
C E_{0-, \iota}^{I} & =C E_{n s n}^{I}+\frac{\alpha_{I}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{(1-R)\left(\beta / R+\widehat{y}^{2}\right)}{(1+2 \widehat{y}) \beta}\right) \\
C E_{0-,\iota}^{U} & =C E_{n s n}^{U}+\frac{\alpha_{U}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)}{\lambda_{U}^{2} \beta R(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Proposition B.1. We start with the insider. From (41), (43), (47) and (48)

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} C E_{0, \iota}^{I}} & =\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} p_{\iota}-\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}\left(X-p_{\iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G, Z_{N}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X} \mid \sigma\left(G, Z_{N}\right)\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

From (49), (72) (recalling that in equilibrium, $V_{0}$ therein is 0 ), (62) and (77)

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]=e^{-\frac{R}{2(1+2 \widehat{y})}\left|\frac{1-R}{R} P_{X}^{1 / 2} G_{0}-\widehat{y} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2}}
$$

Therefore, using (87) we obtain the interim certainty equivalent for $I$ in (89). For the ex-ante certainty equivalent we must compute

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-, \iota}^{I}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} p_{\iota}-\widehat{\psi}_{I, \iota}^{\prime}\left(X-p_{\iota}\right)}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} X}\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{I, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]\right]
$$

Using (88) and the above we obtain

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-, \iota}^{I}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{R}{2(1+2 \tilde{y})}\left|\frac{1-R}{R} P_{X}^{1 / 2} G_{0}-\widehat{y} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2}}\right]
$$

If we re-write this using the notation of $(77),(81)$ we obtain

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-, \iota}^{I}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{R}{2(1+2 \tilde{y})}\left|\frac{1-R}{R}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{\alpha_{R}}} \mathcal{E}_{I}\right)-\widehat{y} \sqrt{\frac{1-R}{\beta R}} \mathcal{E}_{N}\right|^{2}}\right]
$$

We can write

$$
\frac{1-R}{R}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} \mathcal{E}_{I}\right)-\widehat{y} \sqrt{\frac{1-R}{\beta R}} \mathcal{E}_{N}=\sqrt{\frac{(1-R)\left(\beta+\widehat{y}^{2} R\right)}{\beta R^{2}}} \mathcal{E}
$$

where $\mathcal{E} \sim N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$ under $\mathbb{Q}_{0} N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$. This implies

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-, \iota}^{I}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}}\left(1+\frac{(1-R)\left(\beta / R+\widehat{y}^{2}\right)}{(1+2 \widehat{y}) \beta}\right)^{-1 / 2}
$$

which gives the formula in (90). We now consider the uninformed trader. From (42), (43), (47) and (54) we obtain

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{0, \iota}^{U}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} p_{\iota}-\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota}^{\prime}\left(X-p_{\iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{\iota}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} X} \mid \sigma\left(H_{\iota}\right)\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right]
$$

From (75) we find

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right]=e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left|\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right)^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{U, \iota} H_{0, \iota}-\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right) p_{0, \iota}\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right)\right|^{2}}
$$

From (60), (62) and (79) calculation shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(P_{U, \iota}\right. & \left.+P_{X}\right)^{-1 / 2}\left(P_{U, \iota} H_{0, \iota}-\left(P_{U, \iota}+P_{X}\right) p_{0, \iota}\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right) \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{(1-R)^{2}(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\left(\beta-R \widehat{y}(1+\widehat{y})\right)^{2}}{(\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}) R\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}} P_{X}^{1 / 2} H_{0, \iota}
\end{aligned}
$$

From (78) we deduce

$$
(1+\widehat{y})^{2}(\beta-R \widehat{y}(1+\widehat{y}))^{2}=\left(\frac{\lambda_{I}}{\lambda_{U}}(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2})\right)^{2}
$$

which gives

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right]=e^{-\frac{1}{2} \frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)^{2}\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)}{\lambda_{U}^{2} R\left(\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}\left|P_{X}^{1 / 2} H_{0, \iota}\right|^{2}}
$$

The interim certainty equivalent for $U$ in (89) follows from (87) and (47). For the ex-ante certainty equivalent we must compute

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-, \iota}^{U}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} p_{\iota}-\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota}^{\prime}\left(X-p_{\iota}\right)}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} X}\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U, \iota}\left(X_{0}-p_{0, \iota}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0, \iota}\right)\right]\right] \\
& =e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{U}} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)^{2}\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)}{2 \lambda_{U}^{2} R\left(\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}\left|P_{X}^{1 / 2} H_{0, \iota}\right|^{2}}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Using (81) and (83) we deduce

$$
P_{X}^{1 / 2} H_{0, \iota}=\sqrt{\frac{\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}}{\beta(1-R)}} \mathcal{E}
$$

where $\mathcal{E} \sim N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$ under $\mathbb{Q}_{0}$. This gives

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} p_{\iota}-\widehat{\psi}_{U, \iota}^{\prime}\left(X-p_{\iota}\right)}\right]=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{U}}\left(1+\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right.}{\lambda_{U}^{2} \beta R(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}\right)^{-1 / 2}
$$

and hence the ex-ante certainty equivalent for $U$ in (90).

Price-taking certainty equivalents. Here, we consider the price-taking case, with the goal of proving the following.

Proposition B.2. Using the notation of (77), the interim price taking certainty equivalents of Section 3 are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C E_{0}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right)=C E_{I, 0}^{0}(G) \\
& \quad+\frac{\alpha_{I} R}{2\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\left|(1-R) \lambda_{U} P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right) P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2} \\
& C E_{0}^{U}(H)=C E_{U, 0}^{0}\left(H_{\iota}\right)+\frac{\alpha_{U} \lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)^{2} R(1+\beta)}{2\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}(R+\beta)}\left|P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(H-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The ex-ante price taking certainty equivalents of Section 3 are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C E_{0-}^{I}=C E_{n s n}^{I}+\frac{\alpha_{I}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{(1-R)\left(\lambda_{U}^{2} \beta R+\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)^{2}\right)}{\beta\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\right) \\
& C E_{0-}^{U}=C E_{n s n}^{U}+\frac{\alpha_{U}}{2}\left(1+\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R) R(1+\beta)}{\beta\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Proposition B.2. We start with the insider. From (43), (47) and (64)

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0}^{I}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X}\left|\sigma\left(G, Z_{N}\right)\right| \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{I}^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]\right.
$$

From (65), (76), (77) and (84) we obtain after some simplification

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{I}^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]=e^{-\frac{R}{\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\left|(1-R) \lambda_{U} P_{X}^{1 / 2} G_{0}-\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right) P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2}}
$$

Therefore, using (87) we obtain the interim certainty equivalent for $I$ in (91). For the ex-ante certainty equivalent we must compute

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} p-\widehat{\psi}_{I}^{\prime}(X-p)}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} X}\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{I}^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(G_{0}, Z_{N}\right)\right]\right]
$$

Using (88) and the above we obtain

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{R}{\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\left|(1-R) \lambda_{U} P_{X}^{1 / 2} G_{0}-\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right) P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2}}\right]
$$

If we re-write this using the notation of $(77),(81)$ we obtain

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{R}{\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\left|(1-R) \lambda_{U}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} \mathcal{E}_{I}\right)-\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right) \sqrt{\frac{1-R}{\beta R}} \mathcal{E}_{N}\right|^{2}}\right]
$$

We can write

$$
(1-R) \lambda_{U}\left(\mathcal{E}_{X}+\sqrt{\frac{R}{1-R}} \mathcal{E}_{I}\right)-\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right) \sqrt{\frac{1-R}{\beta R}} \mathcal{E}_{N}=\sqrt{\frac{(1-R)\left(\lambda_{U}^{2} \beta R+\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)^{2}\right)}{\beta R}} \mathcal{E}
$$

where $\mathcal{E} \sim N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$ under $\mathbb{Q}_{0} N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$. This implies

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{I}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}}\left(1+\frac{(1-R)\left(\lambda_{U}^{2} \beta R+\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta\right)^{2}\right)}{\beta\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\right)^{-1 / 2}
$$

which gives the formula in (92). We now consider the uninformed trader. From (43), (47) and (64)

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{0}^{U}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} X} \mid \sigma(H)\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U}^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0}\right)\right]
$$

From (76) (with $P_{U}$ replacing $P_{I}$ and $H_{0}$ replacing $\left.G_{0}\right)$, (77), (79) and (84) we obtain after some simplification

$$
\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U}^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0}\right)\right]=e^{-\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)^{2} R(1+\beta)}{2\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}(R+\beta)}\left|P_{X}^{1 / 2} H_{0}\right|^{2}}
$$

Therefore, using (87) we obtain the interim certainty equivalent in (91). As for the ex-ante certainty equivalent, we must compute

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}}=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} p-\widehat{\psi}_{U}^{\prime}(X-p)}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{-\widehat{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime} X}\right] \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{\widehat{\theta}_{U}^{\prime}\left(X_{0}-p_{0}\right)} \mid \sigma\left(H_{0}\right)\right]\right]
$$

Using (88) and the above this is

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}} \mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\left[e^{-\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R)^{2} R(1+\beta)}{2\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}(R+\beta)}\left|P_{X}^{1 / 2} H_{0}\right|^{2}}\right]
$$

From (81), (82) we can write

$$
H_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{\beta+R}{\beta(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1}} \mathcal{E}
$$

where $\mathcal{E} \sim N\left(0,1_{d}\right)$ under $\mathbb{Q}_{0}$. This gives

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}}=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{U}}\left(1+\frac{\lambda_{I}^{2}(1-R) R(1+\beta)}{\beta\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\right)^{-1 / 2}
$$

and hence the ex-ante certainty equivalent for $U$ in (92).
Remark B.3. If we move from the notation of (77) to the notation in (7) we obtain the ex-ante certainty equivalents

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{CE}_{0-, i}^{I}=\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}+\frac{\alpha_{I}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)+\widehat{y}^{2}}{\kappa\left(1+p_{I}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})}\right) \\
& \mathrm{CE}_{0-, i}^{U}=\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{U}+\frac{\alpha_{U}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{\lambda^{2}\left(\kappa p_{I}+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)}{(1-\lambda)^{2} \kappa(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}\right) \\
& \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}=\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}+\frac{\alpha_{I}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{(1-\lambda)^{2} \kappa p+\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(\lambda+\kappa p_{I}\right)^{2}}{\kappa\left(1+\lambda p_{I}+\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}\right) \\
& \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}=\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{U}+\frac{\alpha_{U}}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{\lambda^{2}\left(1+\kappa p_{I}\right)}{\kappa\left(1+\lambda p_{I}+\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# B.5. Proofs from Section 3. 

Proof of Theorem 3.2. Set $c=(1-\lambda) / \lambda, p=p_{I}, \widehat{y}\left(p_{I}\right)=y(p)$ so (6) is

$$
0=(1+y(p))^{2}\left(1-\frac{c y(p)}{1+p}\right)+\kappa p c(1+y(p))+\kappa p
$$

Next define the function (c.f. (27)) as $Q(p, y)=\left[\kappa p(1+p)+y^{2}\right] /[\kappa(1+p)(1+2 y)]$ so that

$$
\partial_{p} Q(p, y)=\frac{\kappa(1+p)^{2}-y^{2}}{\kappa(1+p)^{2}(1+2 y)} ; \quad \partial_{y} Q(p, y)=\frac{2(y(1+y)-\kappa p(1+p))}{\kappa(1+p)(1+2 y)^{2}}
$$

Additionally, from (93) we deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
0= & \left(\kappa+\kappa c(1+y(p))+\frac{c y(p)(1+y(p))^{2}}{(1+p)^{2}}\right) \\
& -\left(\frac{c(1+y(p))^{2}}{1+p}+2(1+y(p))\left(\frac{c y(p)}{1+p}-1\right)-\kappa c p\right) \partial_{p} y(p)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using (93) one can show the quantity in front of $\partial_{p} y(p)$ is strictly positive so that $y(p)$ is increasing in $p$ and hence

$$
\partial_{p} y(p)=\frac{\kappa+\kappa c(1+y(p))+\frac{c y(p)(1+y(p))^{2}}{(1+p)^{2}}}{\frac{c(1+y(p))^{2}}{1+p}+2(1+y(p))\left(\frac{c y(p)}{1+p}-1\right)-\kappa c p}
$$

By the chain rule

$$
\partial_{p} \phi_{i}(p)=\partial_{p} Q(p, y(p))+\partial_{y} Q(p, y(p)) \partial_{p} y(p)
$$

and we wish to show the right side above is positive for all $p>0, c>0, \kappa>0$. To do this we will change perspective. Namely, from (93) we see that $y(p) \geq(1+p) / c$ and in fact $y(p)=(1+p) / c$ when $\kappa=0$. Thus, let us substitute $y(p)=(1+p) / c+z(p)$ so that $z(p)$ solves (uniquely over the positive reals) the equation

$$
0=-\frac{c z}{1+p}\left(1+z+\frac{1+p}{c}\right)^{2}+\kappa p c\left(1+z+\frac{1+p}{c}\right)+\kappa p
$$

Now, fix $p>0, c>0$ and think about $z=z(\kappa)$. It is straight-forward to show that $z$ is strictly increasing in $\kappa$ with extreme values $z(0)=0$ and $z(\infty)=\infty$. Therefore, there is no loss in generality in fixing $p>0, c>0, z>0$ and setting

$$
\kappa=\frac{z(1+p+c+c z)^{2}}{p c(1+p)(2+p+c+c z)}
$$

Plugging in $y=(1+p) / c+z$ and $\kappa$ as above we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{p} Q(p, y(p)) & =\frac{z c(1+p)(1+p+c+c z)^{2}-p(1+p+c z)(2+p+c+c z)}{z(1+p)(2+2 p+c+2 z)(1+p+c+c z)^{2}} \\
\partial_{y} Q(p, y(p)) & =\frac{2 p c((1+p)(1+p+c+c z)+(1+p+c z))}{z(1+p+c+c z)(2+2 p+c+2 z)^{2}} \\
\partial_{p} y(p) & =\frac{(1+p+c+c z)(2+p+c+c z)(z c(1+p)+p(1+p+c z))}{p c(1+p)(c z+(1+p+c+2 c z)(2+p+c+c z))}
\end{aligned}
$$

At this point, if one plugs these values into the right side of (94) and takes a common denominator, the numerator is a sixth order polynomial in $z$. Furthermore, one can directly verify each of the coefficients in the polynomial is positive for all $p>0, c>0$, giving the result.

Proof of Proposition 3.4. From (28) we see that $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{U} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}$ is equivalent to

$$
f(y):=\frac{\kappa p_{I}+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}}{(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}} \geq \frac{(1-\lambda)^{2}\left(1+\kappa p_{I}\right)}{\left(1+p_{I} \lambda+\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}=: \ell
$$

The map $y \rightarrow f(y)$ is strictly decreasing with $f(0)=\kappa p_{I}+1$ and $f(\infty)=1 / 4$. Furthermore, as $\ell$ is evidently decreasing in $\lambda \in(0,1)$ we know

$$
0<\ell<\frac{1+\kappa p_{I}}{\left(1+\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}<f(0)
$$

and hence $k \leq 1 / 4$ implies $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{U} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}$. For $1 / 4<k$, the positive root of $\kappa p_{I}+(1+y)^{2}=$ $\ell(1+2 y)^{2}$ is

$$
\hat{y}=\frac{1-2 \ell+\sqrt{(4 \ell-1) \kappa p_{I}+\ell}}{4 \ell-1}
$$

As shown in the proof of Proposition 1.1, if we define $g(y)$ by the cubic function in (6), then $g(y)>0$ for $0<y<\widehat{y}$ and $g(y)<0$ for $y>\widehat{y}$. Therefore, if $g(\hat{y})<0$ then $\hat{y}>\widehat{y}$ and

$$
\frac{\kappa p_{I}+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}}{(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}}>\frac{\kappa p_{I}+(1+\hat{y})^{2}}{(1+2 \hat{y})^{2}}=\ell
$$

giving the result. It therefore suffices perform the following check: (1) Fix $0<\lambda<1, \kappa, p>0$ and let $\ell=\ell\left(\lambda, \kappa, p_{I}\right)$ as above; (2) If $\ell \leq 1 / 4$ then $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{U} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}$; (3) If $\ell>1 / 4$ then set $\hat{y}=\hat{y}\left(\lambda, \kappa, p_{I}\right)$ and $g=g(\hat{y})$ as above. If $g(\hat{y})<0$ then $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{U} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{U}$. This check can easily be performed by any software tool and one always obtains that either $\ell \leq 1 / 4$ or $g(\hat{y})<0$.

Proof of Proposition 3.5. We prove this result in the setup in Appendix A. Here, recall the certainty equivalent absent private information (88). Using (1) and (70) we obtain

$$
\lim _{\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{I}}{\alpha_{I}}=\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \Pi^{\prime} \mu_{X}-\frac{1}{2 \alpha_{U}^{2}} \Pi^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \Pi
$$

We first consider when $\alpha_{I}=\alpha_{U}$ so that (see (7)) $\lambda=1 / 2$. As such, (28) implies $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{I} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}$ is equivalent to

$$
f(\widehat{y}):=\frac{\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)+\widehat{y}^{2}}{(1+2 \widehat{y})} \geq \frac{\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(\kappa p_{I}+\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(1+2 \kappa p_{I}\right)^{2}\right)}{\left(2+p_{I}+2 \kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}=: k
$$

where $\widehat{y}$ solves (6) with $\lambda=1 / 2$. But $\dot{f}(y)=2\left(y(1+y)-\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right) /(1+2 y)^{2}$, hence $f$ is minimized $(0, \infty)$ at $y_{0}=(1 / 2)\left(\sqrt{1+4 \kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)}-1\right)$, and this value enforces $f\left(y_{0}\right)=y_{0}$. Therefore, $f(\widehat{y}) \geq f\left(y_{0}\right)=y_{0}$ and hence if

$$
y_{0} \geq k \Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{2}\left(\sqrt{1+4 \kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)}-1\right) \geq \frac{\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(\kappa p_{I}+\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(1+2 \kappa p_{I}\right)^{2}\right)}{\left(2+p_{I}+2 \kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}
$$

then $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{I} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}$. Otherwise, $f\left(y_{0}\right)<k$ is strictly less than the right side above, and denote by $\hat{y}$ the unique $y>y_{0}$ such that $f(\hat{y})=k$. As (6) implies

$$
\widehat{y}(1+\widehat{y})-\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)=\frac{\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left((1+\widehat{y})^{2}+\kappa p_{I}\right)}{1+\widehat{y}}>0
$$

$\dot{f}(\widehat{y})>0$ and hence $\widehat{y}>y_{0}$. Therefore, $\mathrm{CE}_{0-, t}^{I} \geq \mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}$ is equivalent to $\widehat{y} \geq \hat{y}$, which as shown in the proof of Proposition 1.1, is equivalent to $g(\hat{y}) \geq 0$ for $g$ defined by the cubic function in (6). However, it can easily be checked by any software tool that either (96) holds, or $g(\hat{y}) \geq 0$. This gives the result for $\alpha_{I}=\alpha_{U}$.

We next fix $\alpha_{U}$ and consider $\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0$. This corresponds to both $\lambda \rightarrow 0$ and $\kappa \rightarrow 0$. As such, we again will write $\kappa=\alpha_{I}^{2} p_{N}$ and appeal to (6) when analyzing $\widehat{y}$. For $\mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}$ one can see

$$
\frac{(1-\lambda)^{2} \kappa p_{I}+\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(\lambda+\kappa p_{I}\right)^{2}}{\kappa\left(1+\lambda p_{I}+\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}} \rightarrow \frac{\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{I} p_{N}+1+p_{I}}{\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{N}}
$$

On the other hand, (6) implies $\widehat{y} / \alpha_{I} \rightarrow\left(1+p_{I}\right) / \alpha_{U}$. Therefore,

$$
\frac{\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)+\widehat{y}^{2}}{\kappa\left(1+p_{I}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})} \rightarrow \frac{\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{I} p_{N}+1+p_{I}}{\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{N}}
$$

The above limits give

$$
\lim _{\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}}{\alpha_{I}}=\lim _{\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{CE}_{0-, i}^{I}}{\alpha_{I}}=\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}} \Pi^{\prime} \mu_{X}-\frac{1}{\alpha_{U}^{2}} \Pi^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \Pi+\frac{d}{2} \log \left(1+\frac{\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{I} p_{N}+1+p_{I}}{\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{N}}\right)
$$

Now, the third order approximation for $\widehat{y}$ around $\alpha_{I}=0$ is

$$
\widehat{y}:=\frac{\alpha_{I}}{\alpha_{U}}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(1+\alpha_{I} p_{I} p_{N}\left(\alpha_{U}-\alpha_{I} p_{I}\right)\right)
$$

and calculation shows $\lim \sup _{\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0} \alpha_{I}^{-4}|\widehat{y}-\widehat{y}|<\infty$. As such, in the limit

$$
\lim _{\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\alpha_{I}^{3}}\left(\frac{\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)+\widehat{y}^{2}}{\kappa\left(1+p_{I}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})}-\frac{(1-\lambda)^{2} \kappa p_{I}+\left(1+p_{I}\right)\left(\lambda+\kappa p_{I}\right)^{2}}{\kappa\left(1+\lambda p_{I}+\kappa p_{I}\left(1+p_{I}\right)\right)^{2}}\right)
$$

we can substitute $\widehat{y}$ in for $\widehat{y}$ to obtain $\left(1+p_{I}\right)^{2}\left(1+p_{I}-\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{I} p_{N}\right) / \alpha_{U}^{4} p_{N}$. Using the above, limit (97), and the fact that $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \log [1+C(x) x] / x=C$ if $C(x) \rightarrow C$, we get

$$
\lim _{\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0} \frac{\mathrm{CE}_{0-, i}^{I}-\mathrm{CE}_{0-}^{I}}{\alpha_{I}^{3}}=\frac{d}{2} \frac{\left(1+p_{I}\right)^{2}\left(1+p_{I}-\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{I} p_{N}\right)}{\alpha_{U}^{2}\left(\alpha_{U}^{2} p_{I} p_{N}+1+p_{I}\right)}
$$

The latter completes the proof of the limiting arguments when $\alpha_{I} \rightarrow 0$.

We finish by proving Proposition 3.6 in the setup of Appendix A, and recalling $\mathrm{CE}_{n s n}^{i}$ from (88).

Proposition B.4. Let Assumption A. 4 hold. As $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$ we obtain almost surely

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{p_{I} \rightarrow 0} C E_{0}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right) & =C E_{n s n}^{I}+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2 \alpha_{I}} Z_{N}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N} \\
\lim _{p_{I} \rightarrow 0} C E_{0, i}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right) & =C E_{n s n}^{I}+\frac{\lambda^{2}}{2 \alpha_{I}\left(1-\lambda^{2}\right)} Z_{N}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the uninformed trader we obtain almost surely

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{p_{I} \rightarrow 0} C E_{0}^{U}(H) & =C E_{n s n}^{U}+\frac{\alpha_{U} \lambda^{2}}{\alpha_{I}^{2}} Z_{N}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N} \\
\lim _{p_{I} \rightarrow 0} C E_{0, i}^{U}\left(H_{i}\right) & =C E_{n s n}^{U}+\frac{\alpha_{U} \lambda^{2}}{2 \alpha_{I}^{2}(1-\lambda)^{2}(1+\lambda)^{2}} Z_{N}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Proposition B.4. From (81), (87), (89), (91) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{CE}_{0}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right)= & \mathrm{CE}_{I, 0}^{o}(G) \\
& +\frac{\alpha_{I} R}{2\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}}\left|\lambda_{U}(1-R) P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-(\lambda_{I}+\beta) P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2} \\
\mathrm{CE}_{0, i}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right)= & \mathrm{CE}_{I, 0}^{o}(G)+\frac{\alpha_{I} R}{2(1+2 \widehat{y})}\left|\frac{1-R}{R} P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(G-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)-\widehat{y} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \frac{Z_{N}}{\alpha_{I}}\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{CE}_{I, 0}^{o}(G)=-\frac{\alpha_{I} R}{2}\left(\widehat{\Pi}^{\prime} P_{X}^{-1} \widehat{\Pi}-2 \widehat{\Pi}^{\prime}\left(\mu_{X}+\frac{1-R}{R} G\right)\right) \\
& (1-R) G=(1-R) X_{0}+\sqrt{R(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}
\end{aligned}
$$

From (6) and (77) we see that $p_{I} \rightarrow 0$ implies $\widehat{y} \rightarrow \lambda_{I} / \lambda_{U}, \beta \rightarrow 0$ and $R \rightarrow 1$. The results for $\mathrm{CE}_{0}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right)$ and $\mathrm{CE}_{0, \iota}^{I}\left(G, Z_{N}\right)$ follow from (88) as $\lambda=\lambda_{I}$ and $1=\lambda_{I}+\lambda_{U}$. For the uninformed trader we similarly obtain (also using (82), (83))

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{CE}_{0}^{U}\left(H_{\iota}\right)= & \mathrm{CE}_{U, 0}^{o}\left(H_{\iota}\right)+\frac{\alpha_{U} \lambda_{I}^{2} R(1+\beta)}{2\left(\lambda_{I}+\beta+R \lambda_{U}\right)^{2}(R+\beta)} \times\left|(1-R) P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(H-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)\right|^{2} \\
\mathrm{CE}_{0, \iota}^{U}\left(H_{\iota}\right)= & \mathrm{CE}_{U, 0}^{o}\left(H_{\iota}\right) \\
& +\frac{\alpha_{U} \lambda_{I}^{2}\left(\beta+(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)}{2 \lambda_{U}^{2} R\left(\beta+R(1+\widehat{y})^{2}\right)(1+2 \widehat{y})^{2}} \times\left|(1-R) P_{X}^{1 / 2}\left(H_{\iota}-p_{\mathbb{Q}_{0}}\right)\right|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
(1-R) H_{0} & =(1-R) X_{0}+\sqrt{R(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{R}{\alpha_{I}} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N} \\
(1-R) H_{0, \iota} & =(1-R) X_{0}+\sqrt{R(1-R)} P_{X}^{-1 / 2} \mathcal{E}_{I}+\frac{(1+\widehat{y}) R}{\alpha_{I}} P_{X}^{-1} Z_{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

The results for $U$ readily follow.

abstract:
We consider a market of risky financial assets whose participants are an
informed trader, a representative uninformed trader, and noisy liquidity
providers. We prove the existence of a market-clearing equilibrium when the
insider internalizes her power to impact prices, but the uninformed trader
takes prices as given. Compared to the associated competitive economy, in
equilibrium the insider strategically reveals a noisier signal, and prices are
less reactive to publicly available information. Additionally, and in direct
contrast to the related literature, in equilibrium the insider's indirect
utility monotonically increases in the signal precision. Therefore, the insider
is motivated not only to obtain, but also to refine, her signal. Lastly, we
show that compared to the competitive economy, the insider's internalization of
price impact is utility improving for the uninformed trader, but somewhat
surprisingly may be utility decreasing for the insider herself. This utility
reduction occurs provided the insider is sufficiently risk averse compared to
the uninformed trader, and provided the signal is of sufficiently low quality.
